results.title: Work
results.creator_credit: Maija Rove and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Dragon’s tongue”.
Colin McKerras introduces this lesson, which centres on work. He introduces vocabulary associated with work, such as “How many days a week do you work?” and “What do you want to do when you leave school?” We see workers in a factory in Beijing and talk to school students about their future plans. The calligraphy section shows the character “to produce” and associated characters for “production”, “products” and “maternity leave” The two dramatised sections “Work or study” which depicts a Chinese family in Australia, and “Work experience” showing a student on work experience assignments, include much of the vocabulary introduced. In Mandarin and English.

results.title: Country life
results.creator_credit: Maija Rove, Asian Studies Council, Griffith University and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Dragon’s tongue”.
This video looks at life in the country in China. It is part of a television series on Chinese language and culture with an emphasis on communication. The video includes an interview with a Chinese duck farmer, a look at Chinese script (the seasons) and short dramas in Chinese. Interview questions are repeated and shown in Chinese script, Pin Yin, and English.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Maija Rove, Asian Studies Council, Griffith University and ABC-TV (Australia)

results.title: Sightseeing
results.creator_credit: Maija Rove, Asian Studies Council, Griffith University and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Dragon’s tongue”.
This video looks at sightseeing in China. Tourist spots like the 13 Tombs are visited. The video is part of a television series on Chinese language and culture with an emphasis on communication. It also includes an interview with a Chinese tourist guide, a look at Chinese script (the city wall) and short dramas in Chinese. Interview questions are repeated and shown in Chinese script, Pin Yin and English.

results.title: School
results.creator_credit: Maija Rove, Asian Studies Council, Griffith University and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Dragon’s tongue”.
This video looks at school and school life in China. It is part of a television series on Chinese language and culture with an emphasis on communication. The video includes an interview with Chinese school students, a look at Chinese script (to study), the erhu (a Chinese stringed instrument), and short dramas in Chinese. The interview questions are repeated in Chinese script, Pin Yin and English.

results.title: Going out
results.creator_credit: Maija Rove and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Dragon’s tongue”.
Episode three covers simple vocabulary associated with excursions to the cinema, a clothes market and the zoo. Vocabulary for clothes and telling the time are included in the two dramatised situations “Sold out” and “Are there any sharks?” The calligraphy section shows the characters for film, television, eye, mirror, glasses, sun and sunglasses. Introduced by Colin McKerras. In Mandarin and English.

results.title: Leisure
results.creator_credit: Maija Rove and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Dragon’s tongue”.
In this second episode we are introduced to simple vocabulary associated with leisure activities and the phrases “Do you like?”, “What do you like?”, “How many times?” as well as vocabulary associated with weather and family members. The calligraphy section shows words which include “ball”, eg. “football”, “volleyball”, etc. The program concludes with two short dramatised situations “The TV addict” and “The Picnic” in which a Chinese couple are introduced to the joys of the Australian barbecue. In Mandarin and English.

results.title: Family and pets
results.creator_credit: Maija Rove, Griffith University and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Dragon’s tongue”.
This first episode introduces the phrases “What is your name?”, “How old are you?” and their answers, “This is”, “He is” and “She is” and words for family members and pets. At the same time we are shown the homes of two different families in Beijing, glimpses of children at school, a zoo visit and the pets the Chinese keep. We also have a brief introduction to calligraphy and how the modern pictograms have developed. Introduced by Colin McKerras. In Mandarin and English.

results.title: Dr. Seuss video classics
results.creator_credit: Ray Messecar, Tish Rabe, Greenlight Media and Random House

results.title: A.S. Neill
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Doubts and Certainties”.
An interview with A. S. Neil, headmaster of the pioneer school of Summerhill in Suffolk for fifty years. Here he discusses Hunkin and his belief that education must not be indoctrination and that the child’s emotions should be completely free.
